material-property-value-condition.content:
Please analyze the following paragraph and summarize the properties, including their numerical values, of the mentioned materials.

Paragraph: Significant progress has been made in synthesis of conjugated polymers and their applications for optoelectronic device such as organic light - emitting diodes ( OLEDs ) , organic photovoltaic cells ( OPVs ) , and organic field - effect transistors ( OFETs ) since Heeger , MacDiarmid , and Shirakawa discovered conducting polymers in 1976.^1 As a result of the low - cost , light - weight , and flexibility advantages , optoelectronic devices based on conjugated polymers are a promising cost - effective alternative to inorganic materials - based microelectronics. Conjugated polymers can be classified as hole ( p - type ) or electron ( n - type ) transporting materials according to the type of orderly transferring charge carriers. Most of conjugated polymers are p - type semiconductors that have seen a dramatic rise in performance over the past decade while much less attention has been devoted to n - type semiconducting polymers that have lagged behind their p - type counterparts. 2 Organic n - type materials are essential for the fabrication of organic p-n junctions , OPVs , n-channel OFETs , OLEDs , and complementary logic circuits. 3 The n - type building blocks are the core components in n - type semiconducting polymers. Aromatic imides such as rylene diimides are one of the classical n - type building blocks and can exhibit relatively high electron affinities , high electron mobilities , and excellent chemical , thermal , and photochemical stabilities. 4 These materials are electron deficient due to the substitution of an aromatic core with one or two sets of π-accepting imide groups that are mutually conjugated. The widely used rylene diimides include perylene diimides ( PDIs , 1 ) and naphthalene diimides ( NDIs , 2 ) ( Figure 1 ). Zhan and co-workers reported the synthesis of the first soluble rylene-based fully conjugated polymer. 5 Top-gate OFETs based on this PDI- dithienothiophene copolymer exhibited a saturation electron mobility ( μ e ) of 6 x 10^-2 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 , current on / off ratio ( I on / I off ) of 10^4 , and a low threshold voltage ( V th ) of 7 V in air. 6 Moreover , all - polymer solar cells based on blends of polythiophene derivative donors and PDI-dithienothiophene copolymer acceptors exhibited power conversion efficiencies ( PCEs ) as high as 1.5% ( AM1.5 , 100 mW cm^-2 ). 7-9 Facchetti et al. reported a conjugated copolymer of NDI and bithiophene ; 10 OFET devices based on this polymer fabricated in a top-gate , bottom - contact configuration with polymeric dielectrics exhibited μ e of 0.1-0.85 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 under ambient conditions with I on / I off > 10^5 . 11 The simplest aromatic imide system is phthalimide ( 3 ) and thiophene imide ( 4 ) ( Figure 1 ). A few literatures reported phthalimide - containing conjugated polymers such as poly-(phenylene ethynylene)s , 12 a polyaniline derivative , 13 and a polythiophene derivative.

Let's think step by step.

1. Conjugated polymers: These are a type of polymer that are used in optoelectronic devices such as OLEDs, OPVs, and OFETs. They have the advantages of being low-cost, lightweight, and flexible, making them a promising alternative to inorganic materials in microelectronics.
2. Hole (p-type) and electron (n-type) transporting materials: Conjugated polymers can be classified as p-type or n-type semiconductors, depending on the type of charge carriers they conduct. Most conjugated polymers are p-type semiconductors, and have seen a significant improvement in performance over the past decade. However, n-type semiconducting polymers have received less attention and tend to lag behind their p-type counterparts.
3. Aromatic imides: These are a type of n-type building block that are used in the synthesis of n-type semiconducting polymers. They are electron deficient due to the substitution of an aromatic core with one or two sets of π-accepting imide groups that are mutually conjugated.
4. Rylene diimides: These are a type of aromatic imide that are widely used in the synthesis of n-type semiconducting polymers. They include perylene diimides (PDIs) and naphthalene diimides (NDIs). These materials have high electron affinities, high electron mobilities, and excellent chemical, thermal, and photochemical stabilities.
5. PDI-dithienothiophene copolymer: This is a type of soluble rylene-based fully conjugated polymer that was synthesized by Zhan and co-workers. Top-gate OFETs based on this polymer exhibited a saturation electron mobility (μe) of 6 x 10^-2 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1, current on / off ratio (Ion / Ioff) of 10^4, and a low threshold voltage (Vth) of 7 V in air. All-polymer solar cells based on blends of polythiophene derivative donors and PDI-dithienothiophene copolymer acceptors exhibited power conversion efficiencies (PCEs) as high as 1.5% (AM1.5, 100 mW cm^-2).
6. NDI-bithiophene copolymer: This is a type of conjugated copolymer of NDI and bithiophene that was reported by Facchetti et al. OFET devices based on this polymer fabricated in a top-gate, bottom-contact configuration with polymeric dielectrics exhibited μe of 0.1-0.85 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1 under ambient conditions with Ion / Ioff > 10^5.
7. Phthalimide and thiophene imide: These are the simplest aromatic imide systems. Phthalimide-containing conjugated polymers such as poly-(phenylene ethynylene)s, a polyaniline derivative, and a polythiophene derivative have been reported in literature.

In summary, conjugated polymers are a type of polymer used in optoelectronic devices, they can be classified as p-type or n-type semiconductors. Aromatic imides such as rylene diimides are a type of n-type building block used in the synthesis of n-type semiconducting polymers. Rylene diimides include perylene diimides (PDIs) and naphthalene diimides (NDIs) which have high electron affinities, high electron mobilities, and excellent chemical, thermal, and photochemical stabilities. PDI-dithienothiophene copolymer and NDI-bithiophene copolymer are examples of n-type semiconducting polymers that have been reported to have high electron mobility and power conversion efficiencies. Phthalimide and thiophene imide are the simplest aromatic imide systems, and phthalimide-containing conjugated polymers have been reported in literature.

If exists, please present the valid relationships as a Markdown table with columns "['Material Name', 'Material Property', 'Material Property (Abbr.)', 'Numerical Value', 'Condition']". Make sure the table items are from the original paragraph.

Here is a table of the material properties and their numerical values mentioned in the paragraph:

| Material Name | Material Property | Material Property (Abbr.) | Numerical Value | Condition |
|---|---|---|---|---|
| Conjugated polymers | Low-cost, light-weight, and flexibility | - | - | - |
| Conjugated polymers (p-type) | Performance | - | Dramatic rise over the past decade | - |
| Conjugated polymers (n-type) | Performance | - | Lagged behind p-type counterparts | - |
| Rylene diimides | Electron affinity | EA | Relatively high | - |
| Rylene diimides | Electron mobility | μe | High | - |
| Rylene diimides | Chemical stability | - | Excellent | - |
| Rylene diimides | Thermal stability | - | Excellent | - |
| Rylene diimides | Photochemical stability | - | Excellent | - |
| PDI-dithienothiophene copolymer | Saturation electron mobility | μe | 6 x 10^-2 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1 | In air |
| PDI-dithienothiophene copolymer | Current on / off ratio | Ion / Ioff | 10^4 | In air |
| PDI-dithienothiophene copolymer | Threshold voltage | Vth | 7 V | In air |
| PDI-dithienothiophene copolymer/polythiophene derivative blend | Power conversion efficiency | PCE | 1.5% | AM1.5, 100 mW cm^-2 |
| NDI-bithiophene copolymer | Electron mobility | μe | 0.1-0.85 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1 | Under ambient conditions |
| NDI-bithiophene copolymer | Current on / off ratio | Ion / Ioff | > 10^5 | Under ambient conditions |

Please note that the values are presented as they appear in the original paragraph, and some of them are ranges, some are specific values, and some are not provided. Also, some properties are not provided with numerical values, but are described as "high", "excellent" or "dramatic rise" which I have included in the table as well.
